avalancheActivity.comment:
The fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The fresh wind slabs can be released easily by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2000 m. The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence above approximately 2200 m.
Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate defensive route selection.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Until the afternoon the wind will be strong. The fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. Some new snow at low altitude.

snowpackStructure.comment: The strong wind will transport the fresh and old snow significantly. The wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and generally at high altitudes. Wind slabs are in some cases small but can be released easily. Avalanche prone weak layers exist in the old snowpack in particular on shady slopes.

avalancheActivity.comment: The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in the high Alpine regions. Wind slabs are easy to recognise.
avalancheActivity.highlights: The more recent wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads,. Some new snow at low altitude.

snowpackStructure.comment: The wind will transport only a little snow. The wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and generally at high altitudes. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are shallow.
